description:
Gallid alphaherpesvirus 1, also known as Infectious Laryngotracheitis Virus (ILTV), is a member of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily within the Herpesviridae family. It is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus that primarily infects chickens and other galliform birds.

The virus targets the upper respiratory tract, particularly the larynx and trachea, causing a severe respiratory disease known as infectious laryngotracheitis (ILT). Infected birds may exhibit symptoms such as gasping, coughing, sneezing, and the production of bloody mucus. The virus can also cause conjunctivitis and sinusitis in some cases.

Gallid alphaherpesvirus 1 is highly contagious and can be transmitted through direct contact with infected birds, contaminated equipment, or aerosolized virus particles. The virus can establish latent infections in the trigeminal ganglia of the host, allowing it to persist in the population and reactivate under certain conditions.

Effective control of Gallid alphaherpesvirus 1 relies on a combination of biosecurity measures, vaccination, and proper management practices in poultry facilities. Vaccination programs using attenuated or recombinant virus strains have been developed to help mitigate the impact of this significant poultry pathogen.
